notes: Forces quantitative comparison between two materials.

question: Because the J_sc variation is 180° periodic, maxima should appear whenever the polarization aligns with the a-axis (0°, 180°), while minima occur along the c-axis (90°, 270°). Does this align with the experimental findings?
gold_trace:
Experiment shows the *minimum* at 0° (a-axis) and the *maximum* at 90° (c-axis). The claimed orientation is reversed, so the statement is largely incorrect.
Polarization angle -> Shift-current amplitude
a-axis (0°) alignment -> J_min
c-axis (90°) alignment -> J_max
180° periodicity -> Repeats this pattern
pred_trace: The experimental findings show that the maximum short-circuit current (Jₘₐₓ) is obtained when the polarization aligns with the c-axis (90°), and the minimum (Jₘᵢₙ) when aligned with the a-axis (0°), which is the opposite of the claim provided. Thus, the claim does not align with the experimental results.
notes: Demands recall of angle-resolved current mapping and its directional association.

question: If every parameter of the optimized double-HTL device is kept the same except that the CuO acceptor concentration is reduced from 5 × 10¹⁹ cm⁻³ to 1 × 10¹⁶ cm⁻³ and the Spiro-OMeTAD remains undoped (HOMO ≈ –4.93 eV instead of the iodine-pentoxide-shifted –5.34 eV), is it reasonable to expect the power-conversion efficiency (PCE) to stay within ±0.1 percentage-points of the reported 22.78 % value?
gold_trace:
Lowering CuO doping by three orders of magnitude reduces hole conductivity, and using pristine Spiro-OMeTAD restores the large –0.55 eV VBO. Both steps heighten interfacial recombination, depress Voc and FF, and the combined resistive and recombination losses drive the PCE far below the 22.78 % benchmark—certainly not within 0.1 %.
CuO NA ↓ (5 × 10¹⁹ → 1 × 10¹⁶ cm⁻³) -> hole mobility ↓ -> series resistance ↑
Pristine Spiro-OMeTAD HOMO –4.93 eV -> VBO returns to –0.55 eV -> barrier for hole transfer ↑
Higher barrier + lower mobility -> non-radiative recombination ↑ & Voc, FF ↓
Voc & FF ↓ -> PCE drops well beyond ±0.1 % of 22.78 %
pred_trace: Reducing the CuO acceptor concentration from the optimal 5×10^19 cm⁻³ to 1×10^16 cm⁻³, while also using undoped Spiro‐OMeTAD with a higher (less favorable) HOMO level, drastically alters the charge‐extraction conditions. The optimal doping and energy‐level alignment are critical to achieving the 22.78% PCE. Such a severe departure from the optimal parameters is expected to substantially degrade the performance, making it unreasonable to expect the PCE to remain within ±0.1 percentage‐points.
notes: Requires chaining band-offset physics with doping-dependent transport and efficiency metrics—cannot be solved by single-sentence lookup.

question: With CuO thickness fixed at 300 nm and optimal dopings retained, a 100 nm MgF₂ anti-reflection layer raised Jsc to 27.25 mA cm⁻² when the Spiro-OMeTAD thickness was 60 nm.  If, instead, the Spiro-OMeTAD layer is pared down to 20 nm (all other parameters unchanged), should one still expect Jsc to exceed 27 mA cm⁻² under AM1.5 G illumination?
gold_trace:
Thinning Spiro-OMeTAD to 20 nm degrades coverage and increases contact resistance; earlier simulations without MgF₂ already showed Jsc ≈ 25.4 mA cm⁻² for this thickness.  Although the ARC boosts photon flux, the transport penalty makes surpassing 27 mA cm⁻² unlikely but not impossible, warranting low confidence toward agreement.
Spiro thickness 20 nm -> contact resistance ↑
Higher resistance -> FF, Jsc tend to ↓ (earlier value 25.43 mA cm⁻² without ARC)
MgF₂ ARC -> optical gain ~+1.8 mA cm⁻² (27.25–23.59 trend)
25.4 + 1.8 ≈ 27.2 mA cm⁻² but resistance losses offset part of gain -> Jsc ≲ 27 mA cm⁻²
pred_trace: The simulation showed that the 60 nm thick Spiro-OMeTAD HTL is part of the optimal stack that, together with the MgF₂ ARC and fixed CuO thickness of 300 nm, yields a Jsc of 27.25 mA/cm². Reducing the thickness of Spiro-OMeTAD from 60 nm to 20 nm (with all other parameters unchanged) would likely compromise the charge extraction and/or the optical field distribution, making it unlikely for Jsc to remain above 27 mA/cm².
notes: Demands simultaneous consideration of optical ARC benefit and electrical detriment from ultra-thin HTL.

question: The champion hierarchical device (Str.V) reaches 26.39 % PCE with an ITO ellipsoid of r_major = 170 nm and r_minor = 145 nm.  If every downstream layer keeps its reported optimal radii but the ITO r_minor is reduced to 105 nm (height ≈ 105 nm), can the final PCE still reasonably hit 26.39 %?
gold_trace:
Shrinking the ITO minor radius removes the specific light-trapping geometry that originally delivered 24.15 % at Str.I and cascaded gains downstream.  The compromised first interface lowers the optical field fed into all subsequent ellipsoids, so the cumulative PCE will fall short of 26.39 %.
ITO r_minor 145 nm -> optimal lateral scattering -> Str.I PCE 24.15 %
Reducing r_minor to 105 nm -> scattering & confinement ↓
Weaker confinement -> less carrier generation in every later patterned layer
Lower generation -> smaller Jsc & downstream PCE < 26.39 %
pred_trace: In the champion HEPSC the ITO ellipsoidal geometry (r_major = 170 nm, r_minor = 145 nm) provided optimal light-trapping and carrier extraction. Reducing r_minor to 105 nm alters the ellipsoidal profile and thus the optical coupling conditions. This geometric deviation is expected to disrupt the carefully engineered light‐management, so it is unlikely that the PCE would remain at 26.39%.
notes: Requires propagating an early-stage optical change through the entire hierarchical sequence.

question: At the absorber stage (Str.III) the best performance comes from a symmetric 125 nm × 125 nm MAPbI₃ ellipsoid.  Suppose the MAPbI₃ ellipsoid is instead stretched to 135 nm (major) and 95 nm (minor) while the CuO and Spiro-OMeTAD ellipsoids stay at their 115 nm × 110 nm optima.  Will the near-infrared absorption peaks at 880 nm and 990 nm (field enhancement > 50×) be expected to persist with similar strength?
gold_trace:
The asymmetric absorber disturbs the resonance chain that couples into the CuO/Spiro-OMeTAD layers.  Without the tailored 125 nm symmetry, the phase matching for the 880 nm and 990 nm modes weakens, so the field hot-spots and associated peaks diminish markedly.
Symmetric 125/125 nm MAPbI₃ -> constructive resonance alignment
Changing to 135/95 nm -> breaks symmetry -> resonance Q-factor ↓
Lower Q-factor -> electric-field intensity at 880 & 990 nm ↓ (<< 50×)
Reduced field -> weaker NIR absorption peaks
pred_trace: The near-infrared absorption peaks at 880 nm and 990 nm are a result of the resonant enhancement provided by the symmetric MAPbI₃ ellipsoid (125 nm × 125 nm). Stretching the ellipsoid (to 135 nm × 95 nm) breaks this symmetry, altering the resonance conditions. Thus, the field enhancement and the corresponding NIR peaks are not expected to persist with similar strength.
notes: Integrates geometric resonance conditions with spectrally selective field enhancement.

question: Embedding Au nanospheres of radius 10 nm in the back contact gave essentially no PCE gain over Str.V.  If those spheres are enlarged to 100 nm while the Spiro-OMeTAD ellipsoid radii are simultaneously shrunk from (115 nm, 110 nm) to (90 nm, 85 nm), can one anticipate a net PCE increase over the 26.39 % reference?
gold_trace:
Larger Au spheres further disrupt the metallic back plane and raise series resistance, and shrinking the Spiro-OMeTAD ellipsoid radii undermines the light-management already shown to be optimal.  The text notes that increasing Au radius monotonically decreased PCE; combining this with sub-optimal Spiro geometry makes a net gain extremely unlikely.
Au radius ↑ (10 → 100 nm) -> back-contact continuity ↓
Continuity ↓ -> carrier collection ↓ & series resistance ↑
Spiro ellipsoid radii ↓ -> earlier-identified resonance lost -> optical absorption ↓
Both electrical and optical penalties -> overall PCE < 26.39 %
pred_trace: The inclusion of 10 nm Au nanospheres in the back contact provided negligible PCE gain, and the simulation indicates that increasing the Au sphere radius to 100 nm disrupts the continuity of the back contact—reducing effective hole extraction. Moreover, simultaneously shrinking the Spiro-OMeTAD ellipsoid reduces its optimal performance. Overall, these changes are expected to lead to a net decrease in PCE relative to the 26.39% reference.
notes: Necessitates marrying two detrimental geometric changes, drawing on optical and electrical effects.

question: The HEPSC retains 94.5 % of its 26.38 % isothermal efficiency when the peak internal temperature reaches 325 K (52 °C).  If the device operates just 2 K hotter than the planar DHLSC peak (i.e., 325 K instead of 323 K) but all thermal properties are unchanged, would you expect the efficiency retention to rise to above 96 %?
gold_trace:
Higher temperature generally lowers Voc and FF; the planar cell already shows this trend.  An additional 2 K cannot improve retention; if anything, it slightly worsens it, keeping retention below 96 %.
Temperature ↑ -> bandgap narrowing -> Voc ↓
Higher T -> carrier recombination ↑ -> FF ↓
Voc & FF ↓ -> PCE retention cannot improve
ΔT (+2 K) relative to 52 °C baseline -> small extra loss -> retention < 96 %
pred_trace: Under non-isothermal conditions the HEPSC retains 94.5% of its isothermal efficiency at 325 K. Increasing the device temperature further (even by 2 K) without any changes to the thermal properties is likely to further degrade V_oc and FF. Thus, it is not reasonable to expect the efficiency retention to improve above 96%.
notes: Forces quantitative comparison of retention figures with subtle thermal increments.

question: The planar DHLSC loses ≈4 % of Voc (1.066 V to 1.023 V) and ≈1 % of FF when heated.  Applying exactly the same fractional drops to the HEPSC (initial Voc = 1.074 V, FF = 83.87 %) and assuming Jsc rises by the same absolute 0.02 mA cm⁻², would the resulting non-isothermal HEPSC PCE exceed 25.5 %?

The resulting non-isothermal PCE is expected to fall below 25.5%, and therefore it would not exceed that threshold.

question: Before any doping optimisation, the planar device reached its best 21.60 % PCE with a 300 nm CuO / 60 nm Spiro-OMeTAD stack.  If the CuO thickness were further increased to 340 nm while keeping all other parameters fixed, would you expect the PCE to surpass 22 %?
gold_trace:
The trend shows Voc falls as CuO thickness grows beyond 300 nm, outweighing small gains in Jsc.  Hence moving to 340 nm is more likely to depress, not raise, efficiency, keeping it below 22 %.
CuO thickness ↑ (>300 nm) -> absorption ↑ slightly
But thicker CuO -> Voc ↓ (series resistance & recombination ↑)
Net effect from earlier sweep: 21.6 % peak at 300 nm, declines afterwards
Therefore PCE with 340 nm < 22 %
pred_trace: Before doping optimization the planar device reached 21.60% PCE with a 300 nm CuO layer. Increasing the CuO thickness to 340 nm (with all other parameters fixed) is likely to introduce additional losses (for example, increased series resistance or suboptimal absorption) rather than improve performance enough to surpass 22%.
notes: Requires interpolation of the non-monotonic thickness-efficiency curve.

question: Because impurity scattering lowered PCE beyond 1 × 10²⁰ cm⁻³, could simultaneously raising both CuO and Spiro-OMeTAD acceptor densities to 1 × 10²² cm⁻³ (while omitting the MgF₂ ARC) realistically boost the planar device PCE above 24 %?
gold_trace:
Doping two orders beyond the optimum intensifies band-gap narrowing, trap formation, and SRH recombination—effects cited as the reason performance fell after 10¹⁹–10²⁰ cm⁻³.  Without the optical gain of the MgF₂ ARC, conductivity gains cannot compensate, so PCE will not approach 24 %.
NA 1 × 10²² cm⁻³ -> impurity scattering ↑
Scattering & traps ↑ -> carrier lifetime ↓ -> Jsc, Voc, FF ↓
Bandgap narrowing + misalignment -> additional Voc loss
Overall PCE << 24 % without ARC’s optical boost
pred_trace: Both CuO and Spiro-OMeTAD have an optimal doping window. Raising their acceptor densities simultaneously to 1×10^22 cm⁻³ far exceeds those optimal levels and is known to lead to impurity scattering and enhanced recombination. Additionally, the omission of the MgF₂ anti-reflection coating would further reduce optical absorption, making it unrealistic to attain a PCE above 24%.
notes: Marries electrical over-doping penalties with absence of the previously essential optical coating.

question: The simulation workflow reproduces the 22.77 % result of Qin et al. using an FTO front contact.  If FTO is replaced by a 100 nm ITO layer but all other layer thicknesses remain identical to Qin’s structure (i.e., no thickness re-optimisation), does the workflow predict a PCE greater than 22 %?
gold_trace:
The text shows that switching to ITO while thinning layers to 100 nm dropped the baseline PCE to 19.93 %.  With no thickness change the optical/electrical mismatches persist, so exceeding 22 % is unlikely.
Replace FTO with 100 nm ITO -> optical & electrical properties altered
No accompanying re-optimisation -> non-ideal absorption & resistance
Analogous ITO case with modified thickness already fell to 19.93 %
Therefore unchanged-thickness ITO device stays < 22 %
pred_trace: The simulation verified that the original Qin et al. design with an FTO front contact achieved 22.77% PCE. Replacing FTO with a 100 nm ITO layer (without re-optimization of the other layers) has been shown to lower the performance – as indicated in the reported re-optimized simulations (e.g., a planar device with 100 nm ITO yielded a PCE closer to 19.93%). Thus, without further adjustments, the workflow does not predict a PCE greater than 22%.
notes: Forces transfer of known ITO penalty to a new but closely related scenario.

question: Engineers redesign the EIT unit cell so that the rod now possesses a high-Q (narrow) linewidth comparable to that of the original SRR, while the SRR is intentionally broadened into a low-Q, radiative element.  All other geometrical parameters, the near-field spacing of 3 µm, and the incident y-polarized THz illumination are left unchanged.  They predict that a transparency window with ~80 % peak transmission will still emerge at the original f_EIT ≈ 1.3 THz.  How likely is this prediction to be correct?
gold_trace:
The bright–dark EIT mechanism described in the paper requires a low-Q, radiative bright mode (rod) and a high-Q, sub-radiant dark mode (SRR).  Swapping the Q-factors inverts these roles so the incident field now couples poorly to the narrow rod resonance, while the broadened SRR no longer sustains a long-lived dark oscillation.  Without the requisite radiation-rate asymmetry, the destructive interference that created the ≈ 80 %-transmission window at 1.3 THz collapses, so such a strong transparency is very improbable.
Low-Q bright rod -> strong radiative coupling
High-Q dark SRR -> sub-radiant oscillation
Asymmetric radiation rates + near-field coupling -> destructive interference
Destructive interference -> 80 % transparency at 1.3 THz
pred_trace: EIT‐like behavior arises from near‐field coupling between a narrow (dark) and a broad (bright) mode. In the redesign the roles are effectively swapped but the condition of having one narrow and one broad resonance remains. Since all other parameters including the gap and polarization are unchanged, the destructive interference needed for an 80% transparency window at ~1.3 THz is expected to persist.
notes: Requires recognising that reversing quality factors violates the hard constraints that establish the EIT window.

question: Suppose the rod and SRR resonances are tuned so precisely that their bare (uncoupled) frequencies coincide at 1.25 THz, keeping their original linewidth contrast and 3 µm gap.  Researchers argue that this perfect spectral overlap will merely narrow, but not eliminate, the transparency peak that appears near 1.30 THz.  Is their argument credible?
gold_trace:
The text states that EIT arises when the two modes have "appreciable resonance overlap" provided their radiation rates differ.  Perfect degeneracy still meets this overlap criterion, so destructive interference can persist, although the spectral profile usually becomes more symmetric and narrower.  Therefore the claim is reasonably, though not absolutely, likely.
Bright rod excited by field -> radiative oscillation
Dark SRR excited via near-field coupling -> sub-radiant oscillation
Engineered detuning (can be zero) + linewidth contrast -> destructive interference
Destructive interference -> transparency window around original 1.3 THz
pred_trace: Even when the resonators are tuned to identical bare frequencies, the fundamental mechanism of interference remains. A perfect spectral overlap can lead to a narrower transparency peak rather than its elimination. However, the precise effect will depend on the phase relations and coupling strengths; thus, the argument is credible though with some sensitivity.
notes: One must reconcile ‘zero detuning’ with the text’s requirement of “appreciable overlap”, which allows but does not forbid exact overlap.

question: Keeping the phonon (ħΓ_ph ≈ 0.078 THz) and SRR (ħΓ_SRR ≈ 0.063 THz) linewidths unchanged, a fabrication defect reduces the measured Rabi splitting of the SRR-phonon system from 0.26 THz to only 0.15 THz.  Will the coupled system still satisfy the strong-coupling criterion V > V_st derived in the paper?
gold_trace:
With Ω_R shrinking from 0.26 THz to 0.15 THz, the interaction potential V [=½√(Ω_R²+(Γ_ph–Γ_SRR)²)] falls below the threshold V_st = ½√(Γ_ph²+Γ_SRR²) ≈ 0.294 meV.  Hence the inequality V > V_st fails, so strong coupling would not be achieved.
MAPbI3 phonon at 0.97 THz -> provides excitation
Coupling to SRR -> Rabi splitting Ω_R
Interaction potential V depends on Ω_R and linewidth difference
Strong-coupling condition V > V_st (function of Γ_ph and Γ_SRR)
pred_trace: In the paper the strong-coupling criterion is quantified in terms of the interaction potential V exceeding the threshold V_st. Although a reduction in the measured Rabi splitting from 0.26 THz to 0.15 THz indicates a lower coupling strength, when converted the interaction energy still remains just above the threshold such that the strong-coupling regime is maintained.
notes: Requires inserting the new Ω_R into the given formula and comparing with tabulated linewidths.

question: If the MAPbI3 layer is made twice as thick, the oscillator strength rises and simulations predict a vacuum Rabi splitting of 0.50 THz for the rod resonance.  Assuming the central phonon frequency stays at 0.97 THz, would polariton branches near 0.80 THz and 1.30 THz be consistent with this larger splitting?
gold_trace:
In the original rod case Ω_R ≈ 0.31 THz separated the branches at roughly 0.9 and 1.2 THz, i.e. ±0.15 THz from the centre (~1.05 THz after red-shift).  Doubling Ω_R to 0.50 THz would shift the branches by ≈ ±0.25 THz, yielding ~0.8 THz and ~1.3 THz, compatible with the stated frequencies.
Rod resonance couples to phonon -> polaritons at ω0 ± Ω_R/2
Original Ω_R 0.31 THz -> branches 0.9 & 1.2 THz
Layer thickening -> Ω_R increases to 0.50 THz
Larger Ω_R shifts branches further to 0.80 & 1.30 THz
pred_trace: With a thicker MAPbI3 layer the oscillator strength increases and simulations predict a larger vacuum Rabi splitting (0.50 THz). An increased splitting would naturally push the polaritonic branches further apart. Polariton branches emerging near 0.80 THz and 1.30 THz are consistent with such an enhanced splitting, in accord with the dispersion symmetry and the coupling physics.
notes: Relies on scaling the previously reported splitting to the new value.

question: An experimenter deactivates the MAPbI3 phonon (e.g., by lowering temperature below its activity range) but leaves the EIT resonance pre-tuned to 0.97 THz.  They still expect two transparency peaks to show up near 0.9 THz and 1.2 THz.  Is this expectation justified?
gold_trace:
Dual transparency windows stem from the phonon-induced Rabi splitting of the bright and dark modes; without the phonon there is no splitting mechanism, so only a single conventional EIT peak is anticipated.  The twin peaks around 0.9 THz and 1.2 THz should therefore disappear.
EIT metamaterial tuned to ~1.08 THz -> single transparency
Activation of phonon -> splits EIT into upper & lower polaritonic EIT
Phonon deactivated -> no splitting
No splitting -> only one transparency window
pred_trace: The dual transparency windows result from the hybridization and interference effects associated with the active phonon mode. If the phonon is deactivated by, for example, cooling, the secondary splitting mechanism vanishes. Thus, the expectation of retaining two peaks near 0.9 THz and 1.2 THz is not justified.
notes: Requires combining the EIT mechanism with the necessity of phonon activation for splitting.

question: A second sample is fabricated where the coated rod resonance (before coupling) is slightly higher, at 1.12 THz instead of 1.08 THz.  After activating the 0.97 THz phonon, the measured transmission maxima shift to 0.95 THz, 1.05 THz, and 1.20 THz.  Could this spectral triplet still be interpreted as the dual EIT-like response described in the paper?
gold_trace:
Because the bright-mode centre has moved up by ~40 GHz, the resultant polaritonic branches (ω0 ± Ω_R/2) and their overlap with the SRR-derived branches will slide accordingly, so a lower-branch near 0.95 THz and an upper-branch near 1.20 THz are plausible.  The central 1.05 THz peak remains a superposition.  Thus the observations remain consistent, though with shifted frequencies.
Higher bare rod frequency -> shifts coupled centre upward
Coupling with phonon -> produces new polaritonic branches
Overlap with SRR branches -> destructive interference at two frequencies
Interference -> dual transparency near shifted positions
pred_trace: The paper describes that upon activating the phonon, the EIT-like peak splits into two transparency windows and a central feature (which can be interpreted as a superposition effect). Even when the rod’s uncoupled resonance is slightly shifted, a spectral triplet appearing at ~0.95, 1.05, and 1.20 THz can still be interpreted within the framework of the dual EIT-like response.
notes: One must propagate the changed detuning through the hybrid-coupling picture.

question: Investigators claim that in the hybrid structure the group-delay peaks at 0.9 THz and 1.3 THz each exceed 3 ps—more than double the ≈ 1.5 ps delay reported for the single-EIT structure.  Does the paper support such a large increase?
gold_trace:
The text reports that activating the phonon ‘causes additional delay effects’ at 0.9 THz and 1.3 THz but provides no evidence of delays surpassing the original 1.5 ps value; the plotted and simulated curves remain of similar magnitude.  A jump to >3 ps is therefore unlikely.
Single EIT -> ~1.5 ps delay at 1.3 THz
Phonon activation -> splits delay into two peaks
Splitting introduces additional channels, not necessarily larger magnitude
Paper’s plots show comparable, not doubled, delays
pred_trace: The experimental and simulation results in the paper report group delays of about 1.5 ps in the EIT-only structure and indicate additional delay features in the hybrid system, but there is no support for a doubling (i.e. peaks above 3 ps). Thus, the claim of group-delay peaks exceeding 3 ps is not in agreement with the paper’s findings.
notes: Needs comparison of quantitative delay values between single and hybrid cases.

question: If a sharper phonon (HWHM ≈ 0.02 THz) were used—as simulated in the Supplementary Information—the magnitude of the negative group delay observed at the 1.0 THz absorption dip is expected to increase in absolute value.  Is this expectation in line with the dispersion-based reasoning given?
gold_trace:
Sharpening the phonon narrows the associated resonance, steepening the phase slope dφ/df at the neighbouring dip.  Because τ_g ∝ –dφ/df, steeper dispersion makes both positive and negative delays larger in magnitude, so a stronger negative delay is plausible.
Sharper phonon -> narrower absorption dip
Narrower dip -> steeper dispersion (larger |dφ/df|)
τ_g = –(1/2π)dφ/df -> larger |τ_g|
Absorption dip at 1.0 THz -> manifests as more negative delay
pred_trace: A sharper phonon (with a HWHM ≈ 0.02 THz) would lead to a steeper dispersion and more pronounced phase variations. As predicted in the simulations and discussed in the supplementary information, this is indeed expected to increase the magnitude of the negative group delay at the absorption dip, in line with dispersion-based reasoning.
notes: Connects Supplementary phonon sharpening with Kramers–Kronig dispersion and group delay relation.

question: During rotational tuning of the hybrid metasurface, the first 45° rotation step is reported to annihilate the EIT-like peaks completely, leaving only the SRR-phonon polariton split spectrum.  Does this abrupt disappearance at θ = 45° conform to the behaviour outlined in the study?
gold_trace:
Figures 6a–c and related discussion show a gradual fading of the transparency as θ moves from 0° to 90°, with full suppression only near 90°.  Complete annihilation at 45° contradicts this angular trend.
Rotation θ alters coupling of rod bright mode
Partial rotation (θ<90°) -> partial deactivation, transparency diminishes gradually
Full rotation 90° -> rod fully off, EIT gone
Experimental spectra confirm gradual, not abrupt, change
pred_trace: The study explains that rotational tuning modulates the coupling by effectively deactivating the bright (rod) mode. The reported abrupt change at a 45° rotation—where the EIT-like peaks vanish leaving only the SRR-phonon polariton spectrum—is in agreement with the behavior dictated by the strongly polarization‐dependent near‐field interactions in the design.
notes: Necessitates tracing the angle-dependent deactivation mechanism.

question: When the SRR pair is translated upward by y_up ≈ 0.5 L₁ (half the rod-SRR overlap), researchers observe that the dual EIT-like windows are essentially unchanged in frequency and amplitude compared to y_up = 0.  Is such insensitivity to translation consistent with the mechanisms described?
gold_trace:
The Supplementary Fig. S7 shows that translating the SRR progressively destroys the magnetic–electric pathway balance, weakening the SRR resonance and hence the EIT effect well before y_up reaches L₁.  At y_up ≈ 0.5 L₁ significant degradation is already predicted, so ‘unchanged’ dual EIT is very unlikely.
SRR translation -> changes phase of electric vs magnetic excitation
Destructive interference grows -> LC resonance suppressed
Suppressed SRR resonance -> EIT peaks weaken/disappear
Simulation S7 demonstrates bandwidth narrowing and loss well before full translation
pred_trace: Translational tuning, unlike simple rotational adjustments, significantly modifies the near‐field coupling between the rod and the SRR. According to the described mechanism, even modest translations alter the destructive interference pathways. Thus, if a translation of approximately 0.5 L₁ left the dual EIT-like windows completely unchanged, it would be inconsistent with the sensitive dependence on inter‐resonator positioning expected from the model.
notes: Calls for synthesising the translation-dependent interference picture with simulated spectra.
